newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Indian state chief seeks to learn from Malaysia.
newsitem.headline: Indian state chief seeks to learn from Malaysia.

text.p: The Indian state of Andhra Pradesh is negotiating 20 billion ringgit ($8 billion) of infrastructure deals with Malaysian firms and the government, eager to learn from their success, officials said on Wednesday.

They said Andhra Pradesh's chief minister Chandrababu Naidu, on a four-day tour of Malaysia, had signed memoranda of understanding with firms for road construction, port development, education, information technology and power projects.
"The response from Malaysian industry has been unprecedented," India's Deputy High Commissioner to Malaysia Deepak Vora told Reuters.
Naidu is leading a delegation of around 30 industry representatives and other officials from his state on the visit to seek investment and "lessons in development" from this fast-growing country.
He said he turned down a shot at India's top job last month to push for the industrialisation of his largely backward state.

"I was asked by my coalition colleagues to stand as a neutral candidate. But, I had my commitments to my state and the development programmes I have started," the 45-year-old leader said in an interview.

Naidu's Telugu Desam party is part of India's ruling 15-party coalition. He says he rejected a coalition request to contend for the Indian premiership after the incumbent lost a parliamentary vote of confidence.
"Fifteen years ago, Malaysia had similar conditions as India. I am planning to (implement the) same model (of development) in India," he said.
"I believe information technology is everything, money, knowledge, wealth.
"I want to bring in administrative reforms through information technology and I want to privatise all things including services (to make them) more efficient," he added.
But Naidu faces an uphill task in convincing a bureaucracy and an electorate more used to welfare programmes of previous socialist governments. India started opening its economy in 1991.
"To start with I am balancing welfare with development. After some time I will give more priority for development. People will have more purchasing power and will be able to survive," he said.

Naidu said other deals expected to be finalised with Malaysian firms were a 500 megawatt power project, the expansion and modernisation of Andhra Pradesh's Visakhapatnam port and a 5.0 billion rupee ($140 million) trade and convention centre.
He has met several senior government ministers, including Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, since arriving on Sunday.

Bina Puri Holdings Bhd announced on Tuesday it has signed a joint-venture agreement with an Indian company, Madhucon Projects Ltd, to build flyovers in Andhra Pradesh state capital, Hyderabad, and a 75-km (47-mile) highway in the state.
Bina Puri's Indian projects are worth 120 million ringgit.
